newsitem.title: ITALY: Uneasy Italian govt allies skirmish ahead of polls.
newsitem.headline: Uneasy Italian govt allies skirmish ahead of polls.

text.p: Italy's uneasy centre-left coalition allies skirmished on Saturday, with Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini and the hard-left questioning each other's behaviour and motives ahead of local polls.
"In the coming weeks the government will have to make difficult decisions to allow Italy to take part in European monetary union from the start," Dini, a centrist, said in northern Italy.

"The majority must be united and Communist Refoundation (the former Communist Party) must consider Europe as a great opportunity for the growth and development of the country," he said as politicians stepped up campaigning for the April 27 local elections.
They are the first solid tests of sentiment since Prime Minister Romano Prodi's centre-left coalition won national polls one year ago.

Communist Refoundation hold the balance of power in the lower house of parliament and last week voted against their allies on sending an Italian-led force to Albania. The vote was carried only with help from the centre-right opposition.
Refoundation, with the trades unions, is also implacably opposed to any changes in welfare spending, and in Italy's costly pensions system, before 1998.

Dini said it was important to convince "our friends from Refoundation...that they must overcome ideological intransigence to join the great objective that is Europe. This is indispensable because there is not much time."
Dini said earlier in an interview with the daily Corriere della Sera that the government must set out its social reform plans by June or consider modifying the coalition.

"The government must define soon, before the summer, a proposed reform of the welfare state undersigned by the entire majority and then negotiate on that basis with the interested parties," Dini told the newspaper.
He said that otherwise Prodi "must have the political honesty to admit promptly -- without waiting until 1998 -- that we are not in a position to take part in the single currency.
"At that point the possibility of broadening the majority to include other centrist forces must be looked into," Dini said, adding that this would be a last resort.
The main Democratic Party of the Left (PDS) within the coalition ruled out changes in the coalition while Refoundation leader Fausto Bertinotti questioned Dini.
Prodi's administration has drawn up a 15.5 trillion lire ($9 billion) supplementary budget in a sustained effort to ensure Italy can join European economic and monetary union (EMU).

That measure was rejected 25 to 24 by a lower house commission on Friday after two centre-left deputies, both former members of Dini's group, voted against the government. The package now goes to parliament for approval.
Bertinotti, whose members also backed the government in the commission vote, said Dini's party "looks more and more like a bridge to the centre-right (opposition)".

Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi has said the government would set out "strategic lines" for pension reforms in its annual document of three-year rolling economic targets (DPEF) to be presented in May.
But Dini told the daily Corriere that the DPEF needed to contain more than guidelines.
"When we ask for an agreement by June we are not doing it for the pleasure of making ultimatums but because time is limited," he said.
"Talks with the unions and employers can only start when a proposal by the entire majority has been defined."
